journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Experimental and numerical analyses of gas–solid-multiphase jet in cross-flow

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering (Ministry of Education), Shanghai Jiao Tong University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Yao Fu, Key Laboratory for Power Machinery and Engineering (Ministry of Education), Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, CN 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: fu_yao@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: In this article, jet influence on a gas–solid-multiphase channel flow was experimentally and numerically studied. The jet flow was found to have a diameter-selective controlling effect on the particles’ distribution. Jet flow formed a gas barrier in the channel for particles. While tiny particles could travel around and large particles could travel through, only particles on the 10 -µm scale were obviously affected. Three different calculation methods, Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes, unsteady Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes, and detached eddy simulation, were used to simulate this multiphase flow. By comparing the calculation results to the experimental results, it is found that all the three calculation methods could capture the basic phenomenon in the mean flow field. Nevertheless, there exist great differences in the transient flow field and particle distribution.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Jet in cross-flow is a common flow structure used both in engineering applications and natural phenomena. Film cooling in a gas turbine blade and exhaustion cooling in a combustor are encountered, for example, in the engineering applications, as natural phenomena correspond to volcano eruptions and pollutant discharge into rivers or atmosphere. Among these examples, film cooling was one of the most active promotions for advancing the understanding of jet in cross-flow. Previous studies focused on the vortex structures as well as their effects on the temperature field and heat transference, while the flow was usually single phase. From these studies, some basic phenomena of the jet in cross-flow were explored. For instance, they emphasized the deflection of the jet in the direction of the cross-flow,1,2 and on the fact that a pair of counter-rotating vortices seem to originate in the near-field and dominate the flow field far downstream.3,4 Also, they pointed out a system of horseshoe vortices similar to the flow around a solid body attached to a wall,5,6 and a complex system of vortices contained in the wake region beneath the downstream side of the jet.7,8

In order to study the basic mechanism of fuel jet in engines and to optimize the distribution of fuel droplets, the previous studies on multiphase jet in cross-flow mostly focus on spray jet in cross-flow. Relevant experimental studies9,10 and numerical studies11,12 were carried out on spray penetration, breakup of liquid jets, droplet collision, etc.

Basically speaking, the numerical Euler–Lagrangian simulation methods used for solid particles and droplets are almost the same, if the droplet mergence, breaking up, and vaporization are neglected. The most important difference in simulation parameters is that the density of particles would greatly affect the particle inertia, and particle inertia would greatly affect the distribution. So, it is necessary to conduct experimental studies on the solid particle distribution in jet in cross-flow.

However, it is a pity that relevant experimental studies are still rarely seen. Lawson and Thole13 made an experiment on a jet in cross gas–solid-multiphase flow in order to study the particle deposition and its effect on heat transfer. The flow was set to simulate the particle deposition effect in a gas turbine channel with film cooling. However, in this reference, the jet influence on particle distribution in the main flow was not studied, which will be the main focus of this article.

In a previous study,14 an experimental system was set up to study the jet influence on particle distribution in a confined domain. It is found that even a low flow-rate jet could obviously affect the particle distribution. Jet flow formed a kind of gas barrier in the channel for particles. While tiny particles could travel around, large particles could travel through, and only the particles on the 10 -µm scale were effectively blocked in the experimental parameters’ conditions. It suggested that the wall jet method could be used as some diameter-selective control method in some engineering applications to affect multiphase flows, for example in inertial particle separator to facilitate the separation of particles, or in a fluid machinery channel to help prevent particles from affecting some vulnerable part.

In our previous work,14 two test conditions were set to simulate two basic flow situations. Test condition 1 had a very high jet velocity. The jet flow was found to impinge onto the upside solid wall, and the jet influence on the symmetric section covered the whole channel height. Test condition 2 had a relatively lower jet velocity while the jet would only affect a limited domain. In a real engineering application of the jet control method, impingement of jet flow could lead to some serious problems, such as higher flow loss, higher flow-rate demand, and unnecessary particle collision to the wall. Therefore, as a further step of the experiments, in order to deepen our understanding of this gas–solid-multiphase flow structure, some additional tests were made in test condition 2 on different sections. The experimental results are shown in this article. Also, different computational fluid dynamics (CFD) methods were used to simulate the multiphase flow in the experiment. Detailed comparisons were to be made among the results from experiments and different calculation methods. Calculation results would help deepen our understanding on the flow structure and jet influence on particle distribution, as parameters and sections not testable in the experiment would be presented in the calculation results.

This article is organized as follows: experimental setup and observations is a simple scan to our experiment including some important parameters are discussed, and readers could refer to the work of Fu et al.14 for more details about the whole experimental system. Numerical method includes some details about the numerical methods used in the study: steady Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) equations, unsteady Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes (URANS) equations, and detached eddy simulation (DES). A detailed presentation, comparison, and discussion of experimental and computational results are presented in the Results and discussion. Finally, some conclusions are summarized in the final section.

sec.title: Experimental setup and observations
sec.p:
The experiments were conducted in a turbulent test section of H × W × L = 0.08 × 0.3 × 1 m3. The main flow – with a mean velocity, Vm, (11.8 ± 0.2 m/s) and center-line velocity, Vc, (13.2 ± 0.7 m/s) – is mixed with a stream of jet flow with a center-line velocity, Vj, (27.2 ± 2.3 m/s). It leads to a velocity ratio M of 2.31 ± 0.24, a main flow Reynolds number Rec of 7.0 × 104, and a jet flow Reynolds number Rejet of 1.8 × 104. A jet tube with a diameter of D = 10 mm is located at the center position on the downside solid wall. Solid particles were carried in the main flow but not in the jet flow. Pictures were taken by the digital particle image velocimetry (DPIV) system on different sections of the channel, as shown in Figure 1, with and without jet flow. Figure 1.
Schematic of the tested channel and symmetric section.

DPIV was used as the main test method. The DPIV system consisted of a Nd-YAG laser, frequency doubled to 532 nm, series of optics to create a light sheet less than 1 mm thick, a Kodak CCD of 4000 × 2096 pixels with 12-bit resolution, a synchronizer, and a computer.

In order to observe the continuous jet influence for each Y-section, three consecutive sections were tested along the streamwise direction. Each section moved 7D downstream the former one. The time-averaged gas flow and particle distribution were merged from the data of these three consecutive sections, which could cover a range from 5D upstream to 20D downstream the jet hole.

Four classes of particles were used in the experiment. Table 1 gives the particle parameters tested by Beckman Coulter Co. LS13 320 particle characterization analyzer. Table 1.
Properties of particles used in the experiment.
Symbol Material ρs (kg/m3) dm (µm) d10 (µm) d50 (µm) d90 (µm) τv (ms) Stj Stm
P1 TiO2 3900 0.3 – 0.0011 0.003 0.00016
P2 Glass 2500 31.85 16.47 31.99 44.84 7.83 21.3 1.15
P3 59.64 43.89 57.04 75.41 27.45 74.7 4.05
P4 114.3 92.34 113.5 138.6 100.81 274.2 14.9

Two kinds of particle Stokes numbers, Stj and Stm, were proposed here. In the previous single-phase studies, the flow was suggested to be primarily dependent on the velocity ratio. But in order to comprehensively describe the particle respondence to both local jet structures and main flow especially when the flow domain was confined, the authors think that it is necessary to propose two different fluid time scales. One is used for describing the jet time scale,τj = D/Vj, and the other one, τm = H/Vm, for describing the main flow time scale. It leads to two different particle Stokes numbers, based on the particle Stokes velocity relaxation time, and the two fluid time scales.
A more detailed description of the entire experimental system could be found in Fu et al.14

All particle distributions and gas velocities were measured using DPIV, which records the particle transient distributions in images and the gas velocity by the cross-correlation calculation of tracer image pairs. For each class of particles on each test section, at least 200 pairs of images were recorded.

Correlated calculations were made to get transient gas flow field. Time-averaged gas flow field was calculated from 200 transient fields. A set of arithmetic relations described in Fu et al.14 are used to distinguish particle spots from experimental images. Also, particle relative concentration fields, throughout the whole 200 pictures for each particle class, were calculated too.

There are several major assumptions made in this study as follows.
The temporal average fluid flow field does not change while adding different classes of particles. The particle flow rate was kept consistent to be 0.74 g/s, indicating a particle volume fraction of 1‰ and volumetric flow rate in the test section of 1.23 × 10−5 m3/(m2 s), which is definitely in the range of dilute flow. The particle collisions with each other were ignored as well.
The sample number, 200 pairs of correlated pictures and 200 transient particle images, is large enough to depict the time-averaged air flow field and particle distribution.
An order of magnitude analysis15,16 has revealed that the forces caused by the virtual mass and the pressure gradient are of the order of density ratio (ρg/ρs), and Basset force is of the order of (ρg/ρs)0.5. In this study, (ρg/ρs) is on the scale of 4 × 10−4. Thus, none of the forces listed upside were to be considered in the analysis.

sec.title: Geometry and grid
sec.p:
The geometric model of CFD simulation is a cubic box of H × W × L = 0.08 × 0.3 × 0.75 m3, as shown in Figure 2, with the jet tube positioned 25D downstream the inlet section. The simulated model is 25D shorter than the geometric size of the experimental test section, so as to lower the grid number. From the former experimental results and CFD simulations, it is found that the jet-influenced region upstream the jet hole is limited in 2D away. To shorten the tube length upstream would merely affect the simulation results. An original 2.5 million hexahedral grid was built. The local magnification of the grid is shown in Figure 3. Figure 2.
Calculation geometry.
Figure 3.
Local magnification of the grid.

In the experiment, some local small-scale vortices were found near the jet hole, as shown in Figure 6(a). In order to simulate these small structures, the original mesh was obviously not enough. Therefore, a steady RANS simulation was made on the original mesh and a mesh-adaptive refinement was taken based on velocity gradient. Then, a further new steady RANS simulation was carried out on the refined mesh. Such refinement processes were taken three times to raise the mesh number up to 4.2 million. The minimum mesh size is 1.02 × 10−12m3, and the y+ of the calculation is less than 10 for both the RANS and DES simulations, which could meet the requirement of the wall function.
The steady RANS computation results from this refined mesh were used as the original flow field for unsteady simulations and would be compared to the unsteady time-averaged results later.
The gas–solid multiphase flow was solved employing the incompressible solver of FLUENT 6.3 and its discrete particle method module.

sec.title: Gas phase simulation
sec.p: Velocity inlet boundary conditions were imposed at the main flow and jet flow inlet based on the experiment conditions. A pressure outlet boundary of an atmosphere pressure was imposed on the channel outlet. The specific pressure data were not tested in our experiment and not of much interest in this study. No-slip boundary condition was imposed at the solid walls.

Three kinds of simulation methods were used in this aricle: steady RANS, URANS, and DES. Actually, the original mesh of 2.5 million was enough for the RANS simulation but in order to exclude the mesh influence and only consider the simulation method difference, all these calculations were carried out on the fine mesh of 4.2 million. Time steps for unsteady simulations were set to 10−4s.

RANS equations were modeled employing RNG k–ε model, as it is more suitable for unsteady turbulent flows and standard wall function. The parameters in the turbulent model are given as: Cmu = 0.0845, C1 = 1.42, and C2 = 1.68. Second-order implicit formulation for temporal discretization, second-order upwind scheme for momentum equation, and third-order monotonic upwind scheme for conservation laws (MUSCL) for k−ε equation were employed for spatial discretization. Pressure implicit split operator algorithm was used for pressure–velocity coupling.

DES is most often referred to as the hybrid RANS/LES (large eddy simulation) model where unsteady RANS is employed to model the near-wall region and LES in the core turbulent region. The present DES model is based on the realizable k–ε model. The length scale in the DES model was defined as d~=min(d,CdesΔ), where d is the distance to the closest wall and Δ the grid spacing based on the largest grid space along the X, Y, or Z directions forming the computational cell. The empirical constant, Cdes, has a value of 0.61. Second-order implicit formulation for temporal discretization, central differencing for spatial discretization of momentum, and third-order MUSCL scheme for k−ε equation were employed.

DES is computationally more expensive than RANS but less expensive than LES since the near-wall is modeled using RANS approach. However, DES involves solving of an additional turbulent viscosity equation.

sec.title: Particle phase
sec.p: Particles were calculated only in the unsteady simulations. The fluid flows were simulated for a certain number of through-flow cycles followed by the injection of particles. Particles were unsteadily tracked at the end of each time step of gas flow field calculation.

Assuming large particle-to-air density ratio, negligible particle rotation, no inter-particle collision, and drag force as the dominant point force, the equations governing the particle motion are given by (1)dxpdt=up (2)dupdt=Fd(u-up)+gx The drag force (Fd) is given by (3)Fd=18μρpdp2CdRep24
Cd is the coefficient of drag force which is given by (4)Cd=a1+a2Rep+a3Rep2 where ai are coefficients related to particle shape, and in our simulation particles, were set to be smooth spheres.

Rep is the particle Reynolds number given by (5)Rep=ρdpg|u-upg|/μ As assumed before, particles’ influence on gas flow field is negligible and not calculated in our simulation. Therefore, the flow is calculated by a one-way coupling method.

At each time step, 5718 particles would be released from the inlet of the channel. After 2000 time steps, which is over 3 flow-through-time-periods (0.8/13.6 s), there are about 3.3 million particles for 0.3 -µm particle in the channel and 3.5 million particles for 110 -µm particle. Based on these data and our simulation results given in ‘Particle phase’ section, it is believed that the number of particles being tracked is sufficient.

sec.title: Mean gas flow field
sec.p: In the experiment, the time interval between two consecutive exposures is 40 µs. The space magnification was 38.8 µm/pixel. The interrogation zone was 32 × 32 pixels, with a 50% overlap between adjacent interrogations. Concerning the space magnification and interrogation region, the relative error of cross-correlation calculation is less than 1% in our study.17

The mean gas flow fields of DES and URANS were calculated over several through flow cycles. In the experiment, only velocities on the main-flow direction, U, and vertical direction, V, were tested. Data related to these two velocities on different sections, obtained from the experiments, RANS, URANS, and DES, are shown in Figures 4 and 5. Figure 4.
Main flow mean velocity U: (a) Y = 0; (b)Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d)Y = 2D.
Figure 5.
Vertical mean velocity V: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D. Note: Velocity ranges on different sections were set different.

As mentioned in the introduction, previous studies1–8 suggested there are four basic phenomena of the jet in cross-flow, which were deflection of the jet flow, counter-rotating vortex pair, horseshoe vortices, and the wake vortices. From Figures 4 and 5, the jet deflection could be clearly observed. Also, the counter-rotating vortex pair, though the streamwise cross-sections were not tested in our experiments, could be indirectly observed from V profiles on sections Y = D and Y = 2D. V on these sections was found negative, which suggested the existence of counter-rotating vortex pair. Horseshoe and wake vortices were transient flow phenomena, and would be analyzed in the section on Transient flow field.

In Figure 4, it seems that the jet flow formed an obvious low velocity wake zone for main flow velocity near the downside wall. In the shear layer, main flow velocity was slightly raised. Vortices in the wake region would be studied from the transient flow data.

For different calculation methods, RANS, URANS, and DES could all successfully capture the basic phenomena described above. Velocity profiles agreed well with the experimental data. It is necessary to note that all the three calculations could get precise velocity peaks’ positions, but there are differences on velocity magnitude, especially near the jet hole. From the main flow velocity, it seems that DES and RANS data agreed better to the experimental values than URANS data. URANS seems to overestimate the jet influence, especially on the section of Y = D. All the vertical velocity values from different calculation methods agreed well with experiment.

From the mean flow field, it could be claimed that jet influence on the gas mean flow field was limited in a range of about ±2D along the traverse direction, and from about −2D to over 15D along the main flow direction. Jet influence seems more obvious and covers a larger domain in URANS than in DES and RANS. In order to analyze the differences between the different calculation methods, a more detailed observation should be carried out on the transient flow field of DES and URANS.

sec.title: Transient flow field
sec.p:
Since it is impossible to find some certain relationships among the experiment time and time steps of different calculation methods, the transient results could only be qualitatively compared. Figure 6 shows the vortex structure near the jet hole from the experiments, DES and URANS. For the experimental case, TiO2 particles, with a diameter of 0.3 µm, were added in the main flow to execute flow visualization. The picture in Figure 6(a) is a magnified part of the local part near the jet hole. Figure 6(b) and (c) are contour pictures of vorticity magnitude from DES and RANS results, respectively. The contour legends of Figures to 8 are the same and shown in Figure 7(a). Figure 6.
Local vortex structure near the jet hole: (a) experiment; (b) DES; and (c) URANS.
Figure 7.
Vorticity on different Z-sections: (a) DES and (b) URANS.

In DES, an LES simulation was carried out in the main flow region. The simulation could successfully depict vortices’ generation and shedding process in the shear layer. In URANS, though an unsteady simulation was carried out, a time-averaged process was originally taken in the equations. Small-scale structures were filtered both by the equations on time and by grids on space. No sub-grid models were imposed. As seen in Figure 7(b), URANS fields show periodic and symmetric structures, and seem much simpler and smoother than DES fields in Figure 7(a).

In Figures 7 and 8, the wake vortices, mentioned above as one of the basic phenomena in this flow structure, could be clearly observed. But the horseshoe vortices were not observed in our calculations. Horseshoe vortices were also not found in some previous LES simulations,18,19 and it was thought to be due to the lack of the resolution in the stagnation region and to the weak structures of horseshoe vortices. Observing the experimental particle distribution pictures, horseshoe vortices were found to have little effect even on the smallest particles’ distribution. Figure 8.
Vorticity on different Y–sections: (a) DES and (b) URANS.

It is shown that the transient flow field is affected in a larger domain than in the mean flow field. Along the streamwise direction, the influence continued to the outlet. Along the traverse direction, the influence covered a range of about ±4D. On the sections of Y > 2D and X > 15D, jet influence greatly depended on the shedding process of large vortices, which is not continuous. That is why the influence was almost negligible in the mean flow field. The vortices’ shedding was a kind of random and non-symmetric one in DES, but periodic and symmetric in URANS. This explained why in Figures 4 and 5 jet influence was more obvious and affected a larger domain in URANS than in DES.
In our simulation, DES apparently agreed to the experiment better than URANS, both on the mean and transient flow field results.

sec.title: Mean particle relative concentration
sec.p: In our previous study,14 a new set of arithmetic was developed to post-process the raw experiment images to eliminate noise and distinguish particle spots.

P(x,y,z) is the number of particles found in a 1 × 1 mm2 region centered at (x,y,z) over 200 images for each particle class. Based on our previous assumptions, 200 transient images for the particle distribution were assumed to be large enough to depict the time-averaged particle distribution. Pm is the mean value of P(x,y,z) over the tested Y-section. In the conditions without jet, particle distribution PConnj is a function of only z-coordinate, and in the condition with jet, particle distribution PConj is a function of x,y,z.
So the relative particle concentration is given as follows (6)PConnj(z)=Pnj(z)/Pmnj (7)PConj(x,y,z)=Pj(x,y,z)/Pmj

In order to eliminate the non-uniformity in the condition without jet, particle relative concentration in the condition without jet was divided from that in the condition with jet. So, the jet influence on particle distribution was defined (8)Infj(x,y,z)=PConj(x,y,z)/PConnj(z) as shown in Figures 9 to 12. Figure 9.
0.3 µm jet influence from experiment: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D..
Figure 10.
30 µm jet influence from experiment: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D.
Figure 11.
60 µm jet influence from experiment: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D.
Figure 12.
110 µm jet influence from experiment: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D.

In Figure 9(a), it could be seen that the jet flow forms a clear and small low concentration zone near the jet hole on the section Y = 0. The influence is obviously lower on sections Y = 0.5D and Y = D. On section Y = 2D, the influence is negligible. However, it is interesting that the influence on sections Y = 0.5D and Y = D seems to last for a longer distance on the streamwise direction than on the section Y = 0. It is thought to be caused by the counter-rotating vortex system. The vortex cores of the counter-rotating vortex system deviate from the Y = 0 section, and the tiny particles were ejected from the vortex cores on the centrifugal force and gather at the outer region. This effect is usually called ‘preferential concentration.’ As the counter-rotating vortex system is the most consistent vortex system in the jet in cross-flow, the vortex core’s influence on the tiny particles also lasts for a long distance on the streamwise direction. That is why the influence on the sections deviating from the middle section would last for a longer distance than the influence on the middle section.

From Figures 10 and 11, the jet influence on 30 - and 60 - µm particles seems similar. Nevertheless, the low concentration zone is smaller and located at a more downstream position for 60 µm particles. The jet flow blocks the particles from entering wake region beneath the jet flow and forms a clear low concentration zone. For these 10 -µm scale particles, the influence on the middle section is similar to that on the Y = 0.5D and Y = D. Also, the preferential concentration effect seems not so obvious for the particles on the 10 -µm scale, because the counter-rotating vortex system is not strong enough to eject 10 -µm scale particles away from the vortex cores. The inertia of 10 -µm particles is so large that it would not be subjected to the turbulent diffusion effect. So, these particles would not restore a uniform distribution as the tiny particles and the low concentration zone last for a long distance. From our experimental results, it is observed that the jet influence on 10 -µm scale particles would last for over 20D.

From Figure 12, it could be observed that, for particles on the 100 -µm scale, the jet influence is almost negligible. Only a very small low concentration zone is found near the jet nozzle. The particles travel through the jet structure and enter the wake zone. The jet flow merely affects the 100 -µm scale particles.

From Figures 9 to 12, a diameter-selective jet control effect on particle distribution could be clearly observed. The jet influence could affect the particle distribution and form a kind of gas barrier for particles. Whereas tiny particles could travel around, large particles could travel through, and the particles on the 10 -µm scale were the only ones affected.

Detailed data from the experiment are shown in Figures 13 to 16 and compared with calculation data. Figure 13.
Comparison of 0.3 µm relative particle concentrations obtained from experiment, DES, and URANS: (a) Y = 0 and (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D.
Figure 14.
Comparison of 30 µm relative particle concentrations obtained from experiment, DES, and URANS: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D. Figure 15.
Comparison of 60 µm relative particle concentrations obtained from experiment, DES, and URANS: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D. Figure 16.
Comparison of 110 µm relative particle concentrations obtained from experiment, DES, and URANS: (a) Y = 0; (b) Y = 0.5D; (c) Y = D; and (d) Y = 2D.

In order to make an effective comparison to the experiment, particle concentration fields from calculation were made non-dimensional by dividing concentration fields with the mean concentration of the tested domain. From Figures 13 to 16, it is seen that though the calculated mean gas flow field matches well with experimental data, particle distribution from DES and URANS all differed from the experiment to some extent. Actually, it is still hard to find a particle simulation method of wide concensus. In this article, more attention was paid to particle distributions from different calculation methods, rather than employing different particle models and trying to find some more appropriate one for this specific flow.

Figures 13 to 16 proved that the small structures simulated in DES but not in URANS, even if they showed little effect on the mean gas flow field, would obviously affect the mean particle distribution. For tiny particles shown in Figure 13, DES seems to give a better simulation result than URANS. As the gas flow mean field obtained from DES and URANS agreed well, as shown in the ‘Geometry and grid’ section, the differences in the particle distribution should be caused by the differences in the transient flow fields, which were the small-scale structures simulated in DES but not in RANS. Due to such structures’ property of randomness, their effect on the mean flow field is negligible. But for tiny particles which could respond to these structures, the diffusion effects are not negligible especially when the particle distribution showed obvious non-uniformity. In our previous experimental study,14 turbulence diffusion was thought to be the mechanism of tiny particles to quickly restore a uniform distribution and not to be obviously affected by the jet flow. In the particle tracking model, no turbulence diffusion model for particle distribution was imposed. Particle’s diffusion only rely on their response to transient flow structures. In URANS, tiny particles would quickly respond to the local velocity gradient, and immediately form a low-concentration domain. Then, particles were transported in the main flow and were only affected by the large structures. Rather than diffusing these particles, large structures would even strengthen particle non-uniformity through ‘preferential concentration’ effect.20 This could be observed from the overestimated concentration peak in the shear layer shown in Figure 13. The low-concentration zone for tiny particles seems more obvious because large structures actually ejected tiny particles from the vortex cores, and gathered them in the shear layer. In DES, in the main flow, though structures were not simulated on all sizes, the random vortices actually had a diffusion effect on particle distribution, and lower concentration non-uniformity. Therefore, it is concluded that URANS is not so apppropriate for tiny particles as DES when no appropriate diffusion models were imposed.

For particles of 30 µm, all the simulations of DES and URANS agreed well to the experimental values. But, because of the same preferential concentration effect as the tiny particles, particle concentration in the shear layer simulated by URANS was obviously higher than that obtained from experiment and DES. As a contrast, DES results agreed better. The jet influence on particle distribution was correctly represented by DES.

For 60 µm particles, DES and URANS give good simulation results, which agreed well with each other. This is maybe because that 60 -µm particles could hardly respond to URANS large vortices or DES tiny vortices.

Surprisingly, in Figure 16, it is found that the simulation results of URANS agreed much better than DES results to the experimental ones for 110 µm particles. In DES, 110 µm particles were seriously affected by the jet and form a low concentration zone just like 30 - and 60 -µm particles. Though the affected domain was just relatively smaller, these large particles were found to be not affected by the jet in experiment. It suggests that though DES shows a better simulation of local vortices, when a Lagrangian tracking was imposed, there still lack of a model of wide consensus for subgrid particle forcing. From the simulation made in this study, it could be concluded that simply imposing an adjusted Stokes forcing model in DES may lead to some problems for large particles.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, jet influence on a multiphase channel flow was experimentally and numerically studied. DPIV was used as the main test method for experiment. RANS, URANS, and DES were used for numerical simulation. Results from different methods were shown and compared.

The main conclusions of this study are summarized as follows.
For the mean gas flow field, RANS, URANS, and DES could simulate the basic phenomena, including the deflection of the jet flow and counter-rotating vortex pair. DES and RANS agreed comparatively better to the experiment than URANS.
DES and URANS showed great differences in the transient flow fields. DES simulations showed randomness in the vortices’ shedding and agreed better to the experiment, whereas URANS showed periodicity and symmetricity. For the basic phenomena in transient flow field, wake vortices were observed in both calculations, but horseshoe vortices were not detected in either calculation.
From the experimental time-averaged particle concentration field, a diameter-selective controlling effect of jet method for particle distribution could be clearly observed. The jet flow formed a gas barrier in the channel for particles, while tiny particles could travel around, large particles could travel through, and only the particles on the 10 -µm scale were obviously affected.
Both URANS and DES results showed some differences in the time-averaged particle concentration field. For tiny particles, DES has a better simulation as the smaller vortices could diffuse tiny particles while in URANS there was a lack of some mechanisms for particle diffusion. But surprisingly, for large particles which barely respond to the jet barrier in experiments, URANS results were found to be better.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by National Science Foundation [grant number 50776056] and National High Technology Research and Development of China [863 Program, grant number 2009AA05Z201].

ref.citation: KefferJFBainesWD. The round turbulent jet in a cross-wind. J Fluid Mech 1963; 15: 481–496.
KrothapalliALourencoLBuchlinJM. Separated flow upstream of a jet in a crossflow. AIAA J 1990; 28: 414–420.
PratteBDBainesM. Profiles of the round turbulent jet in a crossflow. J Hydronaut Div ASCE 1967; 92: 53–64.
Fric TF. Structure in the near field of the transverse jet. PhD Thesis, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA, 1990.

def.p: coefficients related to particle shape (=1, for spheres)
mean diameter of the particle class
length scale in the DES model
10%, 50%, and 90% of the particles in the tested class have a diameter less than these parameters, respectively
mass flux (blowing) ratio of jet to mainstream (=ρjUj/ρmUm)
number of particles found in a 1 × 1 mm2 region centered at (x,y,z) with jet influence
the mean value of P(x,y,z) over the tested Y-section
number of particles found on the height of z in the no-jet condition
particle relative concentration with jet influence
gas phase main flow mean velocity
coordinate of experimental and computational domain, centered at the center point of jet tube exit
relaxation time for particle velocity based on Stokes drag coefficient (=ρsdm2/18μ)
